field_edited_text.value:
VIll. Recommended Development Plans

1. Introduction

Planning recommendations and development
plans for each of the three study areas were
prepared following discussion of the various
alternatives by merchant groups representing
the three areas, city agencies and the Mayor's
Advisory Committee on Small Business.

This represented the first phase of finalizing
and coordinating the various studies. The
recommended plans were accompanied by a
report on design themes and an action program
for carrying out the recommendations.

2. Planning Recommendations and
Development Plans

Plan recommendations dealt with proposals for
land use, traffic and community facilities.
Development plans described the possible
staging of urban renewal projects where these
appeared feasible, and provided cost estimates
for various public improvements, private
rehabilitation and new construction. The
development plans also suggested the types of
new enterprises or facilities that could
complement the existing retail core in each
study area.

A prime purpose of the proposals was to
provide a basis for the total rehabilitation of
each area with relation to specific objectives.
They provide a framework for unified action by
all concerned with the rehabilitation and
improvement program.

Plan proposals were related to planning
objectives and presented in tabular form. They
were accompanied by graphic illustrations of
various plan elements.

The recommendations and plans for each study
area follow:

a. Pennsylvania Avenue Area

The Pennsylvania Avenue plan calls for a major
effort leading not only to rehabilitation but to
the redevelopment of the shopping core. For
that reason, two concepts were preparad, one
considerably larger in scope than the other.
Although the plan for this area suggests a
combination of rehabilitation and
redevelopment, it would be possible to achieve
its objectives through rehabilitation alone, but
over a much longer time. It might also result in

27

the primary objective--the creation of a Tdvyn
Center--not being achieved. ;

The Town Center concept envisages the
creation of a neighborhood focal point as a
center for shopping, community services and
social activity. The plan separates pedestrians
and automobiles by providing pedestrian-ways,
connecting plazas, arcades and shopping areas.
For automobiles, there are convenient parking
lots on the edge of the core area and there are
lanes provided to provide access to buildings in
the core area. Residential buildings are provided
for in the core area to contribute to the vitality
of the unified Town Center and take full
advantage of the convenience of concentrated
services.

b. Light Street Area

The public market was selected as the focal
point and center of activities in the Light Street
area. The market area would help unify the
retail core and identify it as the central point
for traffic approaching from north and south.

The shopping area was proposed as a compact

" center surrounded by residential and office

uses, possibly in multi-use buildings. The
market area would be converted into a
pedestrian plaza and linked by pedestrian ways
to parking areas and shopping arcades in
mid-block locations.

A loop system would direct traffic around the
retail core and be joined to a one-way street
system linking the area with major traffic
routes passing through the area.

The recommendations also included provision
for such facilities as a branch library, and health
and welfare offices serving the neighborhood.

c. Monument Street Area

To take advantage of the proximity of the
Johns Hopkins Hospital complex, a
concentration of core uses closer to the
Hospital was recommended as part of the
process of creating a more compact retail
shopping area. This link between the retail core
and the hospital would be further strengthened
by providing for multi-use buildings
surrounding a pedestrian plaza with retail stores
on the ground floor. The same area was also
suggested as the location for bus and subways
stops.
